# Assignment Objectives {#assignment-objectives}

When starting projects, any idea is a good idea. Let‚Äôs get some started\! You can start from a dataset and then develop questions OR you can start with domain+questions and then go find/collect the relevant data. It‚Äôs fine if you feel lukewarm about your idea, you‚Äôll decide together as a group which idea to go with, and a bad idea can strengthen conviction about good ideas üôÇ.

# Developing Your Pitch {#developing-your-pitch}

## 1. Identify the domain (subject area)
Use an appropriate amount of specificity.

::: {layout-ncol=2}
::: {.callout-tip icon="false"}
## ‚úÖ Good examples of domains
* Explainable AI 
* Healthcare economics 
* Social network analysis
:::

::: {.callout-warning icon="false"}
## ‚ùåBad examples of domains 
* Machine Learning (too broad) 
* Minor 7th dominant cords in Bach symphonies (too specific) 
* Data visualization (too meta)
:::
:::

## 2. Describe a target user of your vis
Use objective observables to describe them that relate to the **task** (check Chapter 3\).

::: {layout-ncol=2}
::: {.callout-tip icon='false'}
## ‚úÖ Good examples of users
* Consumer with a fitness tracker 
* A potential voter  
* Venture capitalist
:::

::: {.callout-warning icon="false"}
## ‚ùå Bad examples of users 
* Myself and/or my friends 
* Someone that doesn‚Äôt understand the data 
* The professor grading this vis
:::
:::

## 3. Describe the main **task(s)**
These could be action/target pairs or analysis question(s) the user of your vis would need to do (check Chapter 3\).

::: {layout-ncol=2}
::: {.callout-tip icon='false'}
## ‚úÖ Good examples of tasks
* Determine how object size affects semantic segmentation boundaries 
* Cluster Goodreads users based on book genre and recommendations 
* Explore the narrative structure of popular Manga
:::

::: {.callout-warning icon="false"}
## ‚ùå Bad examples of tasks 
* To understand the data 
* To learn about Chemistry
:::
:::

## 4. Identify one or more datasets 
These can be exemplars; you are not locked in. Make sure the dataset is available, documented, and of good quality. 

::: {layout-ncol=2}
::: {.callout-tip icon='false'}
## ‚úÖ Good examples of datasets
* [Bird Migration Data](https://dataverse.harvard.edu/dataset.xhtml?persistentId=doi:10.7910/DVN/XEKOWQ) (data was used for a published paper, documentation exists, readable .csv format) 
* [Cityscapes Dataset](https://www.cityscapes-dataset.com/) (benchmark dataset used for many CV/AI/ML papers, lots of code available on internet to process)
* [Iris Dataset](https://archive.ics.uci.edu/dataset/53/iris) (another canonical dataset, straight from an academic lab) 
:::

::: {.callout-warning icon="false"}
## ‚ùå Bad examples of datasets 
* We will scrape Instagram (you probably won‚Äôt have time, data will be messy) 
* We will collect a survey about people‚Äôs habits (designing a good survey is super tricky, takes time) 
* We will request Twitter/X API developer access to collect Tweets (again, no time) 
* Anything like this: [test.csv](https://r.mtdv.me/articles/vital-tips) 
:::
:::

## 5. Find, link, and briefly describe related work
These should be a few related visualizations you've come across while looking into this area. You may want to consider how might a different kind of visualization reveal new insights?

Related work can be ‚Äúrelated‚Äù by being similar in the What-Why-How framework (Chapter 1,2,3) in any of these ways:

::: {.callout-tip icon="false"}
## Ways that related work can be related

* Same/similar domain 
* Same/similar dataset type/semantics (Chapter 2) 
* Similar tasks & target user (Chapter 3) 
* Similar vis type/idiom (Chapter 5, Chapter 7, Chapter 8, Chapter 9) 
* Similar interaction mechanisms (Chapter 11-14)
:::

You can use any visual you find on the internet or in print, but you must be able to trace it back to the original source and cite it.

# Posting Your Pitch {#posting-your-pitch}

Post your pitch (450 words **maximum**) in the \#project-pitches Discord channel.

1. Give your pitch an informative title  
2. Very briefly introduce yourself \+ any info you‚Äôd like to share about yourself   
3. Add a compelling (and related) image that will make people want to click on it to read more. This could be from the site/journal paper where you got the dataset, some of the related works you found, a sketch you drew, a ***relevant*** meme, etc.  
4. Summarize your idea that results from completing steps 1-5 above (domain, users, tasks, related work, data). Include links to examples, data, papers, etc. 
5. Select a relevant tag, or if none fit well, ask me to add a new one\!

![][image1]

## Perusing Classmates‚Äô Pitches {#perusing-classmates-pitches}

I recommend reading through your classmates‚Äô pitches and engaging by asking questions, reacting with thumbs up, or just mentioning that you like the idea because it sounds cool. Maybe as you surf you will have your own idea sparked anew.

# Grading {#grading}

## Originality Checks {#originality-checks}

The following checks will be performed for each submission; If any of these validation conditions are not satisfied, your assignment will be returned to you with or without options for remediation:

- [ ] Check for plagiarism/crappy AI copypaste \- Please refer to the syllabus for the course policy on Academic Misconduct  
- [ ] Check for no cited sources \- You will be notified and asked to resubmit with the required citations within **1 day** of notification, otherwise the Late Policy applies

# FAQ‚Äôs {#faqs}

::: {.callout-note .faq-callout collapse="true" icon="false"}
## What if I have the exact same idea as someone else?  
It‚Äôs fine if multiple people happened upon the same dataset, but the task, related work, and description of the analysis question must be unique
:::

::: {.callout-note .faq-callout collapse="true" icon="false"}
## Our group has already decided what we‚Äôre doing, do we all still have to post a pitch?  
Yes, because 1) the pitch will help you write the Proposal so you might as well, and 2) other students that don‚Äôt have an idea yet will still benefit from seeing your ideas.
:::

::: {.callout-note .faq-callout collapse="true" icon="false"}
## Can I use my own research data, to which there is no public link?  
If you can verify that it‚Äôs well collected and your advisor is fine with you sharing that data, go for it
:::

::: {.callout-note .faq-callout collapse="true" icon="false"}
## Can I use data that I‚Äôm also using for another class Project?  
It‚Äôs great to double dip, just make sure you are not submitting the exact same things for double credit (considered Academic Misconduct and will be flagged by SafeAssign), and your team is fine with you benefitting in this way. If you want to build on work from other courses, you must self-cite.
:::

::: {.callout-note .faq-callout collapse="true" icon="false"}
## Can I scrape websites for data?  
You can try, but you will have a bad time unless you already have the infrastructure and cleaning pipeline set up
:::

::: {.callout-note .faq-callout collapse="true" icon="false"}
## Can I use hardware? (VR/XR System, Magic Globe thingie, Hyperwall, Pico Projector)  
Yes, but please let me know if you need me to buy something ASAP üí≤
:::

::: {.callout-note .faq-callout collapse="true" icon="false"}
## Do we need to mention what tool/framework/software we want to use?  
It‚Äôs not necessary, as this class is about visualization principles, and less about specific tools, but you can mention it if you have an idea
:::

::: {.callout-note .faq-callout collapse="true" icon="false"}
## Can I peruse other student‚Äôs ideas before posting my own?  
Yes! Just be sure to use them as inspiration only and develop your own unique pitch, and @ mention who you were inspired by, and thank them for their cool idea as a comment on their own post
:::

::: {.callout-note .faq-callout collapse="true" icon="false"}
## I don‚Äôt have any ideas  
It‚Äôs fine, come up with *literally anything* that satisfies the specifications in this document. You don‚Äôt need to love it.
:::

::: {.callout-note .faq-callout collapse="true" icon="false"}
## I can‚Äôt pick just one thing!  
Post ‚Äòem all! Just make sure they‚Äôre sufficiently distinct and warrant separate pitches (i.e. not just a different aspect of the same thing)
:::
